Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: EAGER--Evaluating Fluid Inclusion Geochemistry of U-Th Dated Speleothems as a Tool for Resolving Paleoclimate Controversies in the American Southwest
Award.AbstractNarration:
Global hydrologic reorganization throughout the Northern Hemisphere occurred synchronously with repeated large, sub-millennial-scale climate changes in the northern North Atlantic region during the last deglaciation. However, how this reorganization affected the continental hydroclimate in the drought-prone American Southwest remains poorly resolved. Continental-based paleoclimate reconstructions for this region are contradictory in large part due to two sources of discrepancy: (1) uncertainty in age constraints, and (2) fundamental ambiguity in speleothem-based proxy records.

This project-- a collaborative effort between scientists from the University of California at Davis and Harvard University-- seeks to resolve the apparent contradictions in the inferred glacial-interglacial climate reconstructions for the American Southwest using cave deposits from the Sierra Nevada in California. The researchers will employ novel techniques to generate both a robust chronologic framework (using U-Th dating via laser ablation MC-ICPMS) and a record of precipitation (using temperature-dependent noble gas concentrations in fluid inclusions as a temperature proxy independent of other climate processes and stable isotopic composition of inclusion fluids as a more direct proxy of precipitation composition and source region) over the past ~20,000 years at the study site. Successful proof-of-concept of these innovative approaches would open the door for applications to a wide variety of questions in paleoclimate.

The outcomes of this work should lead to better understanding of how climate change impacts the hydroclimate of the American Southwest, an area that is vulnerable to water resource limitation. Additional broader impacts include development of a new facility for routine high-precision U-series dating (of which there are only a handful in the US), development of the noble gas proxy in carbonates, and training of graduate students at two institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Documenting how land surface temperatures have changed during the ice ages is exceeding difficult. Measurements of noble gases dissolved in bubbles of water that get trapped in calcium carbonate cave deposits (speleothems) have the opportunity to shed light on past continental temperatures. That is because the relative ratios of the noble gases dissolved in water are a function of the temperature. However, technical challenges, such as the vast quantities of noble gases in air bubbles trapped in speleothems overwhelm the amount of noble gases in water bubbles, have prevented the technique from reliably yielding continental temperatures.

Our strategy was to release the noble gases in the water bubbles by only crushing (Figure 1) speleothem wafers that were rich in water bubbles – the distribution of the air and water bubbles being mapped by CT-scan and neutron scan beforehand. Additionally, by imaging the distribution of the water bubbles and “popping” them with an UV laser (Figure 2), we planned to measure the noble gases only in the water bubbles and not in the air bubbles.

Our sample extraction line has been modified for speleothem sample analyses to account for the large volume of water hosted within speleothem fluid inclusions. To deal with the problem of separating water from the heavy noble gases, we build a temperature-variable cryogenic trap that has two U-traps in sequence. The two stage cryogenic trap is kept at 180K while sample gas is introduced into the trap. This allows that majority of the water vapor to be captured on the upstream trap. The upstream trap is then warmed to 285K to release heavy noble gases sorbed into the frozen water and any liberated water vapor is distilled onto the second trap. Gas can be cycled through the two traps as necessary to limit the sorption of heavy noble gases with the water vapor. Vacuum crushers and UV laser chambers were designed and build for analyzing the speleothems and we believe we are the only facility in the US that now has the capability to analyze the water bubbles in spelothems using both crushing and UV-lasing techniques.

The project trained a woman graduate student, Jennifer Middleton. She was trained in the use of noble gases in fluids for reconstructing paleo-temperatures and she helped to design the vacuum line and built the speleothem sample extraction line.
